name: Awesomenauts - the 2D moba
description: Use your power, show your might! Play this Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA) game for FREE now! AWESOMENAUTS combines 2D platforming with team-based strategy and hero based action. Whether you are a new recruit or an intergalactic legend, play AWESOMENAUTS!
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 10 Processor: Any processor with 2 Cores Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: AMD or NVIDIA videocard with at least 512MB, or Intel HD Graphics Hard Drive: 3.5 GB HD space Other Requirements: Broadband Internet connection
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 10 Processor: Any processor with 2 Cores Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: AMD or NVIDIA videocard with at least 1024MB Hard Drive: 3.5 GB HD space Other Requirements: Broadband Internet connection

reviews.review_text: after almost 2500 hours i have to say that this game was once upon a time really awesome. butit has gone to hell,, new unbalanced characters and a new patch that no one asked for that changed the whole game play style which makes it rather impossible for a team to make a come back.... the perfect storm for an amazing snowball....... in its current state it is simply lazy and not fun you need a premade team,, you will hate your life while playing this your family and dog too,,dddooonnnttt buyyyyyyy

A great entry level 'Moba' game. Awesomenauts with its quirky characters, 'saturday morning cartoon' art style, fast-paced gameplay and diverse skills offers a unique blend of accessibility, configurability and depth, making it an ideal choice for those who want to sink their teeth into the Moba genre.  I have to admit though, the game is still not a 100% balanced and for some characters, there is little to no variety in builds that are viable when it comes to competetive play. Be ready to be stomped by certain builds that excel on certain maps frequently. Nevertheless, while frustrating at moments, at 20-30 minutes per session, you won't have to spend too much of your time in 'those games'.

I'm sad to add my hat to the pile of negative reviews. Awesomenauts always had a unique sort of charm to it. It's likely the first online game I invested hundreds of hours of my life playing. Ronimo were also the first developers that I really wanted to support. I followed all the streams, bought nearly all the skins as they released and gave 50 bucks to the Starstorm kickstarter.  Unfortunately it's nowhere near as charming as it used to be. The UI used to have character and life to it and the devs kept 'updating' it by removing or streamlining features. The shop redesign was the first thing to make me raise an eyebrow. Awesomenauts used to display all the items in a vending machine kind of setup where you could view all the colorful artwork for each upgrade. It clearly had a lot of love put into it. The new 'improved' shop system was a transluctent sci-fi styled pull out menu with much tinier icons. While I understand Ronimo wanted to expand the amount of items per row from 3 to 6, they could have just drawn more space in between. There have been many other minor UI changes but that was the most saddening to see.  On top of the life being drained from it, I have a lot of issues with the XP system they introduced back in September. That was the final straw for me. I tried for months to play the game anyway figuring it'd grow on me. It did not. I still can't fathom why Ronimo broke their own game so badly. Snowballing matches happened occasionally under the old system, but after XP was introduced they skyrocketed. The solar drops and respawn time on kills were already strong enough ways to gain advantage, but no. That wasn't enough. Now teams gain buffs to damage and health too! Ronimo also stated their intent was to speed up matches that took too long but that wasn't ever an issue to begin with. My most memorable matches were longer ones where the leading team changed back and forth. Games are way too short now and it's much harder to have a match you feel was worth the time spent.  The XP system patch also needlessly complicated other parts of the game. Ronimo multiplied all health and damage numbers by 10 to make it seem like you were doing more. The problem with this is that every number displayed now has 1 extra digit. You can imagine how much this gets in the way during gameplay. I could tell day 1 that hindering every players view of the match was in no way a good enough tradeoff for bigger numbers. Sure you adjust to it but there was really no point in changing it to begin with. Reverting it could only improve on the issue, after all.  You also used to be able to read how much damage you'd gain for taking an upgrade but the added percentage increases with the XP system make this old method impossible. Instead, every upgrade now states the increase as a percentage. This isn't user-friendly at all. In such a fast paced game where you need to be spending as little time as possible browsing the shop, it's incredibly difficult to tell at a glance how effective an upgrade will be when it's displayed as a percentage. I used to be able to see that I'd get 25 (now 250) extra damage per stage. Now your guess is as good as mine, unless you want to be bothered to calculate percentages as your turret continues to be shredded. I don't need to know the exact numbers sure, but a ballpark figure of what I'm capable of dealing would certainly be appreciated. Again with time you could memorize what does what. However, each character added to the roster makes this more and more of a headache.  I sympathize with the developers. I really do. After putting in so much time and effort on a complete overhaul to the game's mechanics, it would be a colossal waste to revert the changes. That's the issue. Ronimo has its hands tied and can't as a company justify going back to the previous system. Unfortunately the game has to suffer for it. I had many great times with Awesomenauts but I cannot recommend this game anymore.

Awesomenauts is a combination of 2D platform/side-scroller with a MOBA (3v3), which creates an interesting combination that turns out as a very enjoyable experience for people who are fond of both genres. Like most 2D platforms, the main mechanics are simple and it's very intuitive, which makes it easy to learn the basics of the game. It's also similar to 2D platforms in how fast-paced it is, and how much it values reaction times. However, it also has some of the depth of MOBAs; there are several characters to choose (16 so far and counting), each one with 2 unique abilities and a different set of possible upgrades to choose for your builds and item routes. This combination results in a game that's simple yet fast and competitive.   In regards to some specific contents of the game:   The developers are active on this game, they produced 15 characters and 4 maps for the base game, plus microtransactions for skins (which doesn't have any impact on the gameplay itself). They'll be releasing an expansion now (currently on beta/early-access) and expand the game from that point on, so if you want to get access to all present and future features (which so far we know are extra characters, maps, spectator mode and custom-setting games), you'll want to buy both the base game and expansion, which is actually really cheap if you buy it on Steam sales or related stuff.   The balance of the game is not top-notch but it's pretty good regardless. New players might feel some characters are OP and whatnot, but once you get used to them you'll realise all of them are pretty much playable and none is 'game-breaking'.  There's a big 'luck' factor in the game. Players are not forced to play a full game and teams aren't required to be full to start and continue games (which means you can find yourself alone with 2 bots in your team vs 3 human players, although this doesn't happen often). Players are allowed to leave a game (although they'll be punished by losing ranking points), this happens very frequently, specially on losing teams, which can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ for both teams (losing teams with bots frequently have no chance of winning, on the other side, you can be on a winning team and new players will join the game and make a comeback). You don't know the map you'll be playing either, which is a problem because some characters have a bigger advantage on certain maps. You don't know what characters the enemy picked either. There's no separated queue for premades and solo players, which is also annoying for a lot of people.  The game netcode is p2p (so, no servers), this is annoying for a lot of players because you won't experience 'input lag' (any actions you'll perform will be instantaneous in your screen), but you will experience a delay in actions of other players (basically you'll see that other enemies will hit you even when it looked like you were out of their attack/skill range). This means that you'll need to deduce the enemy intentions beforehand and estimate the true range of abilities and attacks on your screen based on the player's ping.   Finding full matches is not a problem, and there's a decent amount of players online at most hours, so don't worry about buying a dead game (at least not yet!). There are a lot of players who'll want to play with you and it's easy to make 'queue buddies'.  The pool of characters is not as huge as in LoL or DoTA, but all characters have clear differences and they're all fun to play. Character synergy and team-comps are very important and sometimes if you don't pick your character properly you'll find yourself with a team that is incompetent in teamfights or pushing.  All in all, I think awesomenauts is a great concept and a very enjoyable game, specially for it's price. It's far from being a masterpiece because of it's issues, but despite that, it's a great experience and you'll have lots of fun playing it, specially if you play with friends.

Awesomenauts has fantastic potential, but is not quite there. Tweaks to the balancing and AI will make this one a star.A clever spin on the MOBA genre that strips away the complications and nerdy presentation to create a fast-paced but deceptively complex action strategy game.Awesomenauts has a good and effective mix of genres: platformer, strategy and action. It also has a deep multiplayer with the approachability of a Saturday-morning cartoon.It's surprising just how well the MOBA formula adapts in a 2D environment, it might not be as strategic as others in the genre but it holds its own in terms of how fun the combat is. Special mention also goes to the sound design, very cool soundtrack and each character has their own little jingle, a small touch which I was impressed with, and on top of it all is the great voice acting which adds a welcome layer of charm to an already likebale game. Great concept, great gameplay, much faster-feeling and action-packed than games like LoL or Dota.A brilliant game that's well worth the small price tag.

Played this game quite alot but after several years of abuse from the developers the game circles around 300 players online from earths deepest jungles.  Only hope a serious developer makes a copy of this game and fix the problems that Ronimo (The developer) cannot fix.

Owned this game since release, and I've seen it go through many different iterations.  I can no longer recommend this game because the developers failed to deliver on multiple fronts:  - no dedicated servers, p2p matchmaking is TERRIBLE and the impacts of delay have always been horrid - imbalanced matchmaking for higher ranks because of a dead playerbase - I was routinely in the top 300-500 players when I was active playing back in 2013, and it got to a point where, because I was solo queueing, I could not win games to save my life as they'd be against full rank 1 premades with voice comm. - Starstorm expansion's features haven't been fully implemented, yet Ronimo had the gall to release another paid DLC for the game - Oh, and the addition of the EXP system a few patches ago was the final nail in the coffin. Does nothing to help the snowballing problem this game has always had, in fact it makes it worse because now winning teams can snowball on two fronts - a solar lead (allows you to buy upgrades to your character's kit), AND an xp lead for additional stat increases  Somewhere along the way Ronimo forgot about delivering a quality game and attempted to cash in on what little they've managed to deliver. It's a shame because the art and character style of this game is fantastic. Hopefully one day I can recommend this game again.

For the moment. I have to say no. I feel really bad for saying this.   I feel like Ronimo tipped the boat too far on this new patch. I'm afraid that they may have to balance all the characters over again through their items and once AGAIN with the new EXP based system if Ronimo decides to keep it.   Snowballing happens too quickly, Premades conquer pretty much everything and Solo Queing I feel has taken a big hit in how teamates are now even harder to work with and ignoring minions/droids within the lanes.  Wait for the patch to be reverted or play through the tragedy with us.

Managed to crawl past 3000 hours and I can say for certain the game has no future, it has gotten progressively worse after starstorm expansion, then the XP system. Play it as party game because I have never seen such bad balance in any game before with zero sense of direction. If you want to get good at a game that has a future instead of wasting 3000 hours like I have to find that this doesnt, then I suggest you keep looking. Had huge potential but ruined its about as passive as a floppy weiner.   The characters do not even need to aim and they are far better than most of the cast!

This is a hard game to love, but I do. I've sunk far too much time into it to say I don't love it. It can be extremely fun but also very infuriating.   It's meant to be a casual side-scrolling Moba / Dota-clone and it does that very well, but when I say casual, I mean super casual. Not caring about winning and game-breaking issues casual.   I can handle losing just fine and I couldn't care less about ranking. Being out-played and out-maneuvered comes with any online game. You play until you get better. What I can't handle is losing because you can go 1v3 or the drop-in / drop-out system forcing you to be always down a player because someone forgot they left the oven on and the next person just got a call, so your 3rd is constantly on their way to fight. Or the terrible matchmaking making you join a game where everyone has 300+ ping (yes you can set the game to find only local players but the player base is so small I've had that take 15+ minutes. And then the game is force-started because someone is too impatient).   There's issues involving lag even in local region games that have been around since game launch and continue to persist and will forever persist, because the game uses a p2p hosting model instead of a dedicated server. That cost cutting measure is simply awful and I've been dropped out of MANY games where the host decides to leave and we can't all get connected to the new host, sometimes resulting in the entire match being scrapped.   I've played the game since almost launch, contributed far too much money to the expansion kickstarter and bought some DLC I didn't care about just to support the devs. But I've also uninstalled 6-8 times and quit for months at a time because all the issues got to be too much.   I usually come back after a big patch rollout hoping some more issues are solved, but more often than not it's simply some unless flair added to the GUI and some balance changes which I can rarely understand the reasoning behind.   I've ragged on it a lot and I'm not giving it a thumbs up (in its current state), but I do recommend picking it up, maybe on sale and giving it a shot. Maybe it will have most of my issues with it fixed and if not, at least you can get some good hours out of it.

This game has no servers which makes it a pain to play. The concept however is really cool and I can really enjoy playing games if my host has got an internet connection of more than 100kb/s which isn't usually the case.  IF they decide to run this game on a server someday, it will be one of the best games out there. For now you can just play it if u enjoy raging and being shout at by players that go 0/11 in the first 5 minutes, ragequit and leave you with a suicidal bot.

Well, after . . . 3500 hours? Thereabout. Here's my review of Awesomenauts. Great and addictive game. The only downsides: It needs more players. There is the occasional balance problem, but these are generally rectified quickly, and the ones that aren't are not that extreme. The developers are constantly fine-tuning and adding things to this great game. You'll probably spend less money on this base game and the two major optional DLCs than you would on skins and cosmetics in a free-to-play game like DOTA2 after all is said and done, and get way more out of it.  In short, if you like teamwork, competition, and platforming, buy this game. Buy it now.

This game is really good, i recommend buying it and dowloading the beta that will come within, because the beta is going to implement a whole new matchmaking system and interface! The matchmaking system is one of the only cons of this game, and i'll list the pros below: - Good OST, Characters, Stage, Graphics and Animations. - The whole game besides matchmaking system and fanbase.

Awesomenauts' flaws hold it back from being a truly awesome game.   Pros: Graphics, Sound, Gameplay Cons: Performance  Awesomenauts graphics, sounds, and gameplay all mesh well together to create a more casual, faster paced MOBA experience than its 3D brethren. With only fifteen (nineteen with DLC) awesomenauts, at most two lanes, and one less dimension, the game is more welcoming to newcomers.  With no dedicated servers, however, the performance is mediocre. Disconnects are handled by freezing awesomenauts in place, where they can be killed by enemy creeps or players. There is no way to reconnect once booted from a game, leaving teammates to fend for themselves with a terrible replacement bot. Force starts allow premade teams a huge advantage with 3v1s and 3v2s. Even having a strong connection does not solve the problems if not chosen as host.  Overall, Awesomenauts is simply too unreliable to be anywhere near awesome.  6/10

Don't be fooled. A stylish exterior hides now years of fundamental balance flaws and a never-fixed, dysfunctional matchmaking system not developed for the game's comparatively tiny playerbase. And let's not ignore the double, player-base splitting 'expansions'. They're character packs, nothing else. As if skins and crowdfunders/kickstarters wasn't enough. You could easily mistake this for a f2p at this point.  ...but it's shiny and unique, I suppose.  Seal of Disapproval!

Honestly the game itself is fantastic. The communty has suffered as the years have continued. This I agree with the other posts, but if the commuity is suffering then the best way to fix it is to add better community to the game. Playing this with friends is an awesome time regardless of the fact there can be some seriously uncouth people online. My advice: Play the game and if you want the community to be better then make it better. Honestly if you spent as much time trying to fix it as complaining about it then it could be an amazing community. It definitely used to be.
This game was amazing before the XP system. Remove the xp system, fix the game.

[EDIT] This isn't even the game that I payed for any more. I've given these people money over and over again and instead of getting what I originally payed for they took it away and made into something else entirely. I'm not even angry any more, just upset, like what I thought was the unreasonable behavior of a loved one was just the early symptoms of terminal brain cancer. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This was a great game that provided hours of fun and entertainment, truly reminding me of Saturday mornings as a little kid. Emphasis on the was.   This game was easily my favorite MOBA that I ever encountered, until Ronimo fell for the trap of 'listening' to the fans. The frequent hotfixes and character stat changes have left the game damn near unplayable, taking mains or other characters you enjoy playing as and completely changing how they feel, even completely changing skills/abilities.  The last straw for me was not even the unbalanced Starstorm characters (which I backed on Kickstarter, something I now regret entirely), but rather patch 2.10, which has effectively turned Voltar, the only straight up healer in the game and a solid contender for one of the best supports in any multiplayer game, into a useless squishy blob with no pushing capabilites, no speed, no maneuveribility, and most importantly, an ineffective medic. The one mechanic that was changed to improve him was his increase in DPS for his Drone ability, which works- for anything left completely alone or an afk player, because his drones will actively target everything on the map other than actual threats coming up on top of you.  Buy this game on sale, it goes for 90% fairly often, but don't expect to be playing this game for more than a couple of weeks- the magic will wear off and you'll find yourself left with a mediocre game that doesn't know what it wants to be, and never will as a long as Ronimo keeps on addressing problems that the vocal few 'fans' keep bringing up, instead of taking a good hard look at the product and figuring out what needs to change.

I used to love playing Awesomenauts, but that was only when it was at it's beginning stages and had some good gameplay and balance (It wasn't perfect but it worked). It's now 3 years after I purchased the game and I would never go near it again. The community isn't the best fall of salty users that get butt hurt over one lose on their account and refuses to ever take the blame that they actually were the fault to the lost. There is most likely 1-2% people that play the game that are actually nice and i'm very good friends with to this day. The balance has gone and looks as if it's never coming back, Romino seem to care more about making the game look good in screenshots then when actually playing it. The devs are lazy unless something is really broken and stops people from playing and they start to care because they lose money.  - Ronimo asked the community for a kickstarter goal of $300,000 to created a simple DLC... which ended up reaching over $500,000! - The DLC content literally could have been done for free and then the DLC sold because they did nothing other than create some new characters.. which they do for free randomly all time! - The DLC 'nauts' are usally broken and op when first released, seems to happening everytime a new DLC 'naut' comes out but never when a standard free 'naut' is released. *cough p2w? *cough*  Long story short, save your money for a game where it's devs care about the community and the gameplay of their game and not just about making money.

Enjoy the idea of MOBAs but just aren't any good at RTS games? No problem. Ronimo got your back. By fusing the MOBA concept with a 2D platformer, they made a game that's quite simply: Awesome!  There are some issues of course, mainly the matchmaking system. But just like LoL before it, it has improved a lot since it launched.   Like most MOBAs, it's still preferable to be played with friends but at least the community isn't as nasty as most other online games. From my personal experience anyway.   On the more technical side, the game is really pretty. The animation is really smooth, and the art direction is top notch, provided you like the idea of playing a game that satires 80s saturday morning cartoons.   I definitely recommend this game to anyone with an interest in MOBAs or online multiplayer games.

Fun for a game now and again. But if you want to play a moba where the devs pay attention to what the players want, how the game should be balanced, or I don't know, care. This is not the moba for you. With the only thing resembling a competititve scene being dominated by 99c, and the 'Prestigious League 1 for the 250 best players' is a total joke. The game isn't hard, the queues and matchmaking are awful to put it lightly. Combine that with very few characters to play, let alone are viable. One of the 'draws' of the game is that it has a very low skill ceiling and a high skill floor, and is supposedly easy for new players to enjoy and play. Again, this is not true. The difference between a good team and a bad team is noticable immediately into the game, and has very little to keep the player playing. The unlock system is completely arbirtary. See, while other mobas like League or SMITE force you to play the game for a while to unlock the things you want, you get to choose what things you want. In Awesomenauts, you have no choice whatsoever about what you unlock. Are you a frog player? Do you see all of these fancy items and great builds that other frogs have? Do you want those items? Well you're going to have to play about 30-35 hours of the game before you can get to that point, oh and I should mention that you can unlock these things faster for winning games, which is near impossible with the disgustingly bad stock items. As for the matchmaking, it's total trash. The matchmaking servers matches you with player within 2 leagues above and below you. Let's take the average League 3 player, not outstandingly good, but still good enough to be about top 8000. You can get matches with anyone from League 5 (roughly top 20000) to League 1 (top 250). If the game can't find anyone within those 5 leagues you can be matched in, it will take literally anyone and put them in your game, for better or for worse. Now this wouldn't be an issue with the game, if it had draws to keep players playing (which it doesnt) achieving League 1 wouldn't be hard if it weren't for the outright broken matchmaking, and even then so few tournaments are held with so small prizes almost always dominated by the same 3 or 4 teams. The devs have absolutely no direction and little involvement with the community, the game is easy with little to no reward for being good, matchmaking and soloqueueing is cancerous beyond description, I haven't even touched on the DLC which for $10 awards players with 4 characters who are absolutely dominant in the current meta (if this game could even be considered as having a meta), the balance is constantly changing with every patch and the devs are putting time into things noone cares about, games are near impossible to win if you're on your backfoot in even the first 5 minutes, everything about this game is maddening to say the least. If you want a good F2P moba, go play Dota 2. If you want a moba thats easy to get into, go back to Call of Duty.

The game is incredibly fun. It is a cross between a Platformer and a Moba. Two of my favourite genres. The characters feel unique and the in-game music is fantastic. You can never get tired of the killing spree music.  Compared to other Mobas this feels easier and more fun to pick up. The item builds are more straightforward, so I never felt the need to look up any guides or anything. If anything figuring stuff out on my own has made me a better player. This is a bit more twitch reflex, fast paced Moba.  Since the matchmaking update, you get better matches and less ping between players. Though be warned that if you live in an area where there aren't a lot of players matchmaking might match you with bots as there are no suitable players for you to be matched with. I haven't had issues with this my self. But had a couple of friends who couldn't get a match after the matchmaking update. Mainly people outside EU and US have been having such issues.   Also as any other moba, people are pretty childish and will not hesitate to waste their energy to insult you. If you feel affercted by toxicity, there is an option to disable the chat altogether.  Ronimo is, in my experience, a very transparent company and has continued to improve the game through years. Sometimes it means they make a big change and it might upset some people, but overall they have continued to improve and support the game for years. Which is more than I can say about a lot of other more major developers who have abandoned their games and communities.  I would recommend anyone who enjoys Moba or Platformer genre to give this game a try. Base game is often on sale, so I would recommend putting it on your wishlist and trying it out.

Before XP Update: Wow this game is great! After XP Update: Wow this game is horrible!  Meanwhile at Romino: 'No one is liking the new XP update, should we get rid of it? Lol no let's just put in a DLC in an attempt to get their minds off of it :)'

Awesomenauts brings a fresh spin on a familiar format. It performs adequately with the formula we're familiar with in team-based DOTA style games: you have lanes, turrets, minion waves, and a base. Choose your character, destroy enemy structures. Pretty standard stuff.  Where Awesomenauts stands out is in it's character. The art and gameplay transport us back to the golden age of 2D side-scrolling, bringing back memories of (insert your favorite 2D title here) while you savor the smart-mouthed slams each of the 'nauts bring to the battlefield. You'll find yourself addicted, and in short order.  That said, the limited community for the game precludes Ronimo from separating premade teams from solo players. What this means for you is that a match will frequently be slanted heavily against you if you play alone. On the same token, the converse is true.  Overall, I'd give it 4 rainbow unicorn poops out of 5.

As someone who has been playing this game ever since it was released on PS3/XBOX 360 back in May 2012, I REALLY want to recommend people to play this game. There is a lot of fun in this game due to the 2D side-scrolling gameplay, which I find very interesting for a MOBA game back in 2012, and the fun characters including new ones (most of which is free) that roll out overtime. The maps can be challenging as cetain characters can take advantage of it. For example, when Ayla's Rage can damage driods under the area of top turrents (which I find BS sometimes) at Ribbit IV. Sentry's Black Hole Sun applies too as this ability can drag and hold players when placed under them despite some form of ground inbetween the players and the hole. Another thing I like is that matches are pretty fast compared to popular MOBAs like League of Legends, DOTA 2, etc. You don't have to spend almost an hour on ONE match. In Awesomenauts, the average match is about 15-20 minutes with the longest I've experienced is about 40 minutes (this is before the XP system).  But as I outweigh the pros and cons of this game, I find that the cons are  slightly  higher than the pros, especially with the new XP system. As some people mention it before, the purpose of the XP is to make matches go faster by creating a snowball effect. Any kills, whether it is creeps, driods, or other players, will raise their team level. On paper, the idea is great since in the past, there were some matches that drag out too long. As for execution, this is debatable. People who win a lot with this system will likely say there's little to no problems with it. People who lose a lot with this system will likely say the XP system is broken and unplayable. Personably, as someone who used to win a lot of games before, I can agree to the fact that this can be a problem. The XP system requires to have little to no mistakes when playing because every kill is exp points for the other team. Pair this up with the  WONDERFUL  matchmaking, those claims that this is unplayable may have some truth in it. The old system makes you work hard to gain a victory. The new system is on drugs as anybody, no matter what rank/league you are in, can simply win if one team is screwing up. It's subjective to how everyone feels about the XP system, but everyone can agree that this can be frustrating when you are paired up with team members who are either new to the game, new to the character they are playing as, or has no sense of teamwork or coordination. And honestly, I suffered way too much with that.   Other things to note is that there are no ranked matches, there is no surrender option, and there are matchmaking issues. For ranked matches, I don't understand why this does not exist since we have leagues/tiers, ranked points, and such. I want to play with experienced people without the need to go over to community and organize games. Not all of us has the time to go over to the fourms and ask if people wany to play. For me, I play it like a lot of multiplayer games: hit the matchmaking button and hope the team you are in is actually good. For surrenders, why isn't this a thing? If a game is going very bad to the point where you and your teammates cannot do anything but feed the enemy team, why can't we be given the option to surrender instead waiting for the enemy team to destroy almost every turrent and finally destroy the base. This happens way too often even though I tried to carry my team. I think we can prevent a good amount of people ragequiting and going AFK instead of waiting for the match to be over. If time is the issue (like people wanting to surrender less than five minutes in the game), then set the limit to activate surrunder at the 8-10 minute mark. For these two issues, it has been almost  four  years and Ronimo still haven't resolved this, or rather walked around it. Lastly on the  AMAZING  matchmaking, we can all agree that we had experienced being with bad teammates against very good players or being placed into a match where the team you are in has only one turrent left a handful of times. I understand that Ronimo is trying their best, especially since they are just indie developers, but why not just give us the option to choose a game instead of the matchmaking be random. Why not give us the option to prevent us from joining mid to late games randomly? This is infuriating because I have experienced this crap for so long.  It is also note that you lose more rank points if you leave a game versus losing a game (for those of you who care about your rank). While this encourages people to stay in their match and finish it (or wait till you lose), any disconnect is considered a leave. To be clear, leaving a game means losing half the experience points towards your league and unlockable skills (especially if you prestige) when you win a match. It may seem like an annoyance, but this is a warning for people who is tempted to leave a match just to find a game you can win in.  I know this is a very long review, but this is a game I have put so much time in since its original release, and only to feel like being stepped on due to these problems. And the thing is, I want this game to succeed. This game has a lot of potential to be a unique MOBA game that is diferent than the typical and popular MOBA games out there. If anything, I want to say that Awesomenauts is my favorite MOBA, but I can't. The game had undergone a lot of changes, for better or worse, over the years, and while it is not as bad as most people who didn't recommend this game says it is, this game still need a lot of tuning, epecially ever since the new XP system. I know the Overdrive expansion is coming soon with it promising better matchmaking. But as it stands right now, be very, very wary when considering to buy this game along with the Starstorm expansion. Wait for a sale if anything.   TL;DR : The game is mixed IMO due to frustrating issues, both common and personal, that has not been resolved or has been walked around. Wait for a sale.

Okay, I will admit at first I HATED this game... But I will also admit I was bad at it. Really bad. The game has a bit of a learning curve. But now, I like it. I wouldn't quite say I love it, but I'd say it's worth the $10.. even though I got it for 99 cents. :D  It's basically a base/tower defense game with 2D cartoon aliens.  I think there's like 20 different characters now, and that's exactly what they all are, different. Each and every character is unique. There are no 2 characters where you think 'Hmm, this one is kinda like that one' They all look different, and they all have their own special abilities. Pick up solar(games currency) or gain it by killing, and you get to upgrade those abilities. It definately helps to either read up on all the characters abilities, or have an experienced friend to play with you. What you don't know, kills you... Over and over and over. Overall, it's really a good game. I only have one problem with it. Leon. Leon makes me sad. No matter what character I am, no matter how upgraded I am, he finds me, pops out of nowhere, and out-DPMs me no matter what I do. Of all the deaths I have in the game, I'd say 90% are Leon related.  Get the game, it's worth it. Not sure? Wait until it goes on sale. But before you make your judgement on whether or not you like it, play every character. That's the secret, you have to find the character that you like and do okay with, then continue to learn and progress from there. Don't just try 1 character and say you hate it, because that's what I did. Learn from my mistakes.  P.S. Leon OP, please nerf. 9/10

For the better part of two years, I watched this title on the steam market, maybe like you are doing now. Being a pretty enthusiastic videogame consumer, this title seemed to sink into the background for me even when it appeared on the front page after an update. The thing that tripped me up was my conception of what actually constitutes a a 'MOBA' game.   Lateley people seem to think of MOBA games as stemming from some starcraft or warcraft mod with a tedious learning curve, an awful playerbase, and very slow-paced strategic combat.  THIS IS NOT THE CASE HERE.  Awesomenauts is a Multiplayer Online Battle Arena which pits two teams of three agains one another. Each player may choose a character from an evolving list of 'Nauts' catering to their own unique playstyle. Throughout the match, players are able to purchase upgrades for their characters moveset. Upgrade by killing enemy 'creeps' (enemy AI units which give gold, aka 'Solar') and kill the ever-loving crap out of the enemy team.  As opposed to a conventional MOBA like DoTa 2, there is no long farming phases, the shop system is easily understood, the mechanics are fast and tight direct controls, as opposed to clicking for movement, and the upgrade combinations provide the reletively easy-to-learn movesets with a huge bag of varied playstyles for each character.  The action in any given match is literally nonstop from the moment you rocket down in your jetpod. Immediately the teams rush at one another trying to get an early kill for a leg up early on, and everyone brawls making risky chase attempts and desparate retaliations. With every trip to the shop the scales get tipped, and it becomes very easy for a team to go from underdog to victor if teamwork is utilized.  As for the features of the game, there are several that set this game apart from an others I've played  Local Co-op is always a big thing for me. In my opinion, gaming is about experiencing cool events and challenges as a social event involving more than one person. The fact that I can play this game on the couch -conveniently, even- with my roommate who has never even touched the typical MOBA game is really cool!  The Art Style and character concepts are so totally unique, I can't say I've come across anything quite like it. This makes for a fresh new continuity with lots to discover and master!  All I can advise for those on the edge about purchasing Awesomenauts is to throw out your conception of an Isometric, slow, boring, grind-fest MOBA and imagine a gale-speed battle of force, reflexes and wits. Awesomenauts is truly the ultimate test of platforming, fighting, and skill.

A few things to expect if you buy Awesomenauts:  The matchmaking issues have never been fixed. There is no unranked play. You frequently get matched in to ongoing games. When the community is at its usual height (meaning not during a sale) you will very frequently get dropped in to matches that are well beyond lost. Quitting out and re-queuing will often get you dropped right back in to the same FUBAR match. You'll find yourself playing with bots against a premade team more often than 'naut.   When there is not a sale, a majority of the active players are very experienced. They will let you know that power creep has made many of the base characters pretty useless. Without Starstorm, you'll find yourself on the receiving end of a lot of beatings. There are a couple of base characters that see a good amount of high-end play, but ask yourself if you really plan to commit that much time to this game. The pool of honestly useful characters is pretty limited.  There are no dedicated servers. There are no region settings. This results in a lot of games where ping will be 200 or greater. You'll be stuttering around slowly while the other team ruins your day. And it will happen a lot.  I've not played with the Overdrive expansion, but I don't see any of its characters topping any leaderboards.  I've seen plenty of rumblings that the new XP system causes some real matchmaking inequality. Remember, there is no unranked play. The learning curve of any MOBA is pretty steep, and it gets much worse when you're stuck in a constant stream of losing matches with only bots on your team to teach you.  If you can overlook these faults, the game is mechanically sound and visually appealing. The original music is mostly pretty great.

Awesomenauts is a 2D 3v3 platforming MOBA with the style of 80s cartoon. I've sunk alot of time into this game and I've had a blast with it, and still do.  Pros: -15 Unique characters with thier own upgrades that you can customize to fit your unique playstyle, -Each character has thier own theme music as well as killing spree music -Split screen capable up to 3 players -Controller support, but plays just as awesome with keyboard and mouse -Competitive Community (via the Awesomenauts Pro League) -4 maps with unique platforming and terrian obstacles -AI Modding support to make better bots -Easy to learn, hard to master -Quick matches normally taking 20-30 minutes per match.  Cons: -Some of the community can be toxic -A couple of maps favor some nauts better than others -The 'drop-in, drop out' system of the game which many have faults with because Awesomenauts was originally a 'casual' MOBA styled game. -Unable to coordinate with your teams before a match begins to see what characters they may be playing as or what map you are playing on next (The first part can be fixed by using a voice comms [Skype, Mumble, TS3, etc]) -Some people don't like how you have to obtain XP from completing matches to unlock new characters and loadout items for each character.  Notes: There is also an expansion which is in development but will be bringing things like: -Spectator Mode -Replays (Released) -5 characters (4 released) -New map -Custom games to play different modes such as Team Deathmatch -Many other features  I would also like to add one more note that even if you don't have the expansion, you can join a friend's custom game to play on the new map as well as play custom game modes through joining your friend.  Overall rating: 9.5/10

Awesomenauts is a 3-on-3 2D MOBA game. You start out with a limited selection of ‘Nauts, but unlocking the other ones is done rather quickly. Eventually, you’ll have a selection of 15 heroes to choose from (19 if you also purchased “Starstorm”) each with 2 special skills and a regular attack. Further levelling up of your profile will unlock special features for your skills, like lower cooldowns or larger range. So people who have played longer will have a wider variety of features in their skills. Awesomenauts also doesn’t have a steep learning curve like other MOBA games, so it’s fairly easy to jump into the game and get playing. However, it’s still varied enough to not grow stale quickly and the skill ceiling is high enough to keep you playing and trying to improve.

As you probably might guess by the Awesomnauts' cutesy artstyle and wacky character design this game was built around the idea of creating a casual and arcady 2D MOBA. The idea was executed well: gameplay is indeed largely twitch skill based, yet most of the mechanics familiar from DOTA clones were preserved. Learning curve is pretty mild and the game is satisfying to play right off the bat. There is a sufficient degree of complexity in terms of metagame, so it's not entirely meaningless, but superior platforming skill can definitely elevate even the crappiest of builds to a point where you might be an asset to the team. There is also a pretty varied roster of characters, all with their own style and personality. On top of that, devs are still adding new content, which gives you incentive to come back regularly, as it almost guaranteed to feel fresh again.  The few gripes I have with it are not related to the core gameplay as much as they're basically inevitable problems that this game has to face as a multiplayer game run by a small indie studio and a (sort of) MOBA. One of them would be the occasional toxicity you might encounter in the game. It can be upsetting and annoying, but it's still slightly better than in LOLs and DOTAs. Matchmaking is another problem. The issue here lies in the basic reality that there simply aren't enough concurrent players at any given time to make the algorithm work well so the result is oftentimes you end up in very lopsided matches and unequal team members. The best remedium for this is to play with friends, that way it won't affect you nearly as much. There is also a huge chasm between what the most dedicated part of the community, those who play in League 1 and 2, wants and what all the rest wants and sometimes it seems like the devs don't quite know how to deal with these conflicting demands which sometimes leads to some balancing issues. But that's rather a minor complaint as this state never lasts for very long and eventually returns to equilibrium.  With all that said, Awesomenauts still has me going back to it and despite my frustrations I can still say that it's still ton of fun and I recommend it without any hesitation.

A fantastic collaberation of the Side-Scrolling Platformer and Moba genres crossed with some fighting game elements. And while it certainly has it's problems, such as various glitches which the devs are working on fixing at this very moment and a few balance problems, this game is well worth looking in to.   Much like any other Moba-style games, or competitive games for that matter, Awesomenauts is very difficult to master. I personally have thrown 1000+ hours into the game and I'm still not that great. However unlike quite a few games out there which I will not name, it is very easy to get into the game and have a fantastic time.   Rather than spending the first fifteen or so minutes doing nothing but killing the creep waves and maybe some minor poke, it is completely possible to engage in a team fight within the first few minutes of a match, keeping it exciting for everyone participating.  If I were to rate Awesomenauts, I would give it a 7/10. The score should be higher, however there are some outstanding issues which I just cannot pass over, such as a Peer to Peer connection system which quite often matches you against players with insane ping levels, or the fact that certain characters can't make jumps that other characters can. However it is still an immense amount of fun and I have found that after 1000+ hours I'm still not bored of the game, do check it out!

DO NOT BUY THIS S H I T GAME.  中文版本：  有一句话是这么说的：“陪伴是最长情的告白”，关于这个游戏，我差不多玩了有3000+小时，作为及其少数从1.0版本一直走到现在的玩家，我只能说，我尽力了，真的。  当初寥寥无几的那些人，大部分人还是盗版。但是我依然在为这个游戏的推广而努力。在看到巴西玩家一起写信给Ronimo然后出了巴西语言之后，我们以华人玩家的身份给游戏公司写信希望能出官方的汉化，游戏公司回复我们也许会在未来考虑这一点，但是现在由于技术问题我们做不到。我们表示理解，毕竟是一个小公司，不能强求太多。甚至我们有想过能不能和3DM合作一起出一个外挂汉化发给游戏公司，然后我就去和3DM的版主去联系了，如果有心人还记得的话，那个版主叫杀中杀，虽然后来我们闹崩了。然后为了争取在国内普及这个游戏，对于制约最大的语言问题，我赶在我某个假期的最后放弃了其他所有的事情在三天内做出了第一版的翻译，我一点一点做的英雄的详细资料，包括背景故事，基础的信息，各种技能以及升级的的解释 。并且在每次版本更新的时候都要去自己一个人去维护他，只能说我耗费了30%的精力投入到这个游戏上面，我真的尽力了。我不想抱怨什么，因为所有的语言在事实面前都是苍白无力的。  然后关于星爆，当时群里的人特别兴奋，毕竟按照官方的说明，应该是一个会让人为之振奋的版本，在线观战，回放，大厅，Workshop，5个英雄2张地图，但是直到现在Starstrom还没有完成，但是在这种情况下，Ronimo选择的是出新的英雄出新的DLC，出新的皮肤播音员。Ronimo你可曾考虑过玩家的感受？  我不想提游戏关于英雄的平衡是这样的：哪个英雄这段时间玩的人特别多胜率也不错，那么好，这个英雄太强了我们需要砍一下。对于那些没怎么有人玩，胜率低的英雄，那么好，这个英雄太垃圾了，我们要增强一下。你们就是这么平衡英雄的？？不过看了Ronimo的直播之后我觉得，他们也只能这样平衡了，因为他们实在是菜的一笔。根本不知道怎么样去平衡英雄。为了让超频OverdriveDLC买的人更多，不惜一切来加强超频里的三个英雄，我也真的是服气了。  在Ronimo的官网上曾经有这样的一张计划图，评测没法贴图我就直接复制了。 • Custom games browser • Third batch of Custom Games options • Online replays • Infinite spectator mode • Level editor • Steam Workshop integration • Starstorm map + song • Digital artbook • Backer mentions in the droppod area • New Matchmaking   大厅已经被他们放弃了。连一个简简单单的在降落区对捐款玩家的感谢，以及雕塑到现在都没有做出来。还有一张星爆地图也没有做出来，就更不用说观战模式，Workshop，在线录像。  之前想举办一个比赛，我去给官方写信问能不能给我们几个Roboscoop皮肤来当做奖品，我们想尽可能的在中国推广这个游戏，官方是这样回复我的，抱歉不能给你皮肤，但是我们正在弄简体中文，希望这样能帮你推广这个游戏，并且有可能后续需要你们的帮助来维护。当时听到之后很振奋，真的。在有生之年说不能定见到简体中文也不枉我这么多年的心血。但是随着第一次Beta的测试，心碎了一半。这垃圾汉化，一个大写的服气。再加上新的匹配机制的垃圾到不能再垃圾而且对于中国玩家强烈的不友好。我仿佛已经能看到这个游戏的终点了。  今天和Sauce老师一起测试了一下新匹配，我们俩150ping，但是2s一次红三角，然后一次红三角10s。这很王牌真的。  用一句话来形容，有心杀贼，无力回天。  我累了，仅此而已。  抱歉。

Awesomenauts is a curious mix of MOBA / DOTA-like and platformer. Requiring more twitch skill than last-hitting ability or proper build order, this is a game in two worlds.  The art style is cartoony, specifically designed to invoke the feelings of old saturday morning cartoons like Ren & Stimpy or Tom & Jerry. Slapstick humor is certainly prevalent all around and many of the character's lines are referrential; they even have a few big name internet celebrities doing character voices (TB, Jess Cox, dodger, and Myndflame are the ones i know of). Overall the game is fairly pretty with interesting variations between the maps.  The game is very easy to get into as you level up incredibly quickly and early on most people don't know what they're doing, so you won't need anything but some good ol' Mario skill and common sense to get started, though i do reccommend playing practice mode first.  The gameplay is tight and responsive, though it could be a teeny bit quicker on the uptake. There is a drastic problem though; the game De-syncs ALL THE TIME. I have had numerous games where I was kicked due to severe lag and sync problems due to low ping. EDIT: the game is hosted peer-to-peer. Do not play without serious antivirus software and firewalls or you could possibly get hacked. The game also has no games lobby of any sort, automatically searching for a game to get you in. This exacerbates the low-ping problem as you have no idea how god the host of the game is, and it's very reluctant to switch hosts. This problem will get you unfair kills and unfairly killed time and time again. Ronimo, if I have any reccomendation, fix this issue BEFORE releasing starstorm fully. However, if you can get past that, there's a surprising amount of depth to the game. Each character plays very differently despite having only 2 abilities and a special jump. The characters all also have their own items, and you get to customize which items are available to buy at the shop, which is where a great deal of the non-twitch skill comes in. Setting up proper builds is daunting, so i suggest taking an online build to begin with, then working on your own from the principles you see there.  EDIT: A lot of people hav e complaints about the community in the game. For me and my under 20 hours at low levels, I have seen a few complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and one feeder, but overall people are quiet and react as you'd expect a normal person to; upset when losing (but not blaming the team except for the feeder, who was literally doing nothing so i don't blame him.), happy when winning (but only a few ♥♥♥♥♥ who spam the taunt button or act all superior when they win at league 9 [of 9]) and talking to the team only to ask for help defending a turret or something. I give it a community toxicity rating (with 1 being friendly and helpful while 10 being DOTA 2 or the youtube comments section.) of 6. More bad than good, but acceptable if you're patient and level-headed.  Overall, the game is funny, can be challenging, has great depth, but at the same time still feels like a beta test sometimes. As for starstorm, I don't have it and am reluctant to pay money for extra characters in any game, despite it being a pretty cheap character pack. One final thing; this is a paid game with microtransactions. On the other hand, it's only cosmetic (unless you count starstorm which also has an extra map coming and AI editor) so you decide if that's fair.  If you like platformers and competitive games and don't mind a bit of glitchiness and don't have a problem with the fact that if you want totalbiscuit Vinne you've gotta shell out extra real cash, The game comes recommended. I play it a ton and have enjoyed my time immensely. Using Nerdcubed's 1-3 rating system; I give awesomenauts a 2. This is without a doubt not a shining recommendation; the game has a laundry list of problems some of which can be fixed while others are the result of the good ol' internet community. I personally picked it up for 99 cents but I wouldn't have paid much more for it. Certainly not 10 dollars.

Awesomenauts is Awesome!  3v3 side scroll Moba game with great 2D graphics and effects, perfect for old-school side scrolling battle fans!  you control 1 character that have unique skills for each of them, then you collect solar coins which is in-game currency to upgrade that skills to be more damaging, more power, less cooldowns, etc, you can setup your build before each battles to suit what playstyle you wants, nuker? support? or Tanks... and you battles with 2 more allies on your side, which have different abilities characters, you fight with other 3 characters that have different skills, and playstyles.  the objective of this game is to destroy enemy's Drillcore which is in the deepest part of their base, and defended by turrets, droids spawns each couples of second to help you destroy those turrets, and don't forget that the enemies also have people to defend their turrets, so you have to balance between defending and attacking to win the game  the only downside of this game is its connection-based server, if the host have bad connection, you'll get massive lag in the battles, but the mechanics of the game can migrate server based on the best connection player in-game, so it doesnt really matters much on the long run  definitely must have!! :)

I've been watching this game for a long time and this year I decided to buy it on summer sale when I saw it cost. I was a little bit distracted by recent reviews though I wanted to try the game by myself. Fortunetely most of the problems mentioned above dont exist: I had no problems with MM or lags, game is perfectly enjoyable, especially for this cost so If you hesitate - just dont be afraid and try it.  Pros: -rather small number of characters, though every one of them has a unique playstyle and differs from others MUCH - smooth and enjoyable gameplay, well designed mapS(!) -2d perspective (you have to aim) and nauts design results in a lot more balanced gameplay than in big MOBA titles -art style, graphics and sound almost(?) perfect -very good and unique for every character itemization system which works around evolving abilities (sth similar to HOTS, but way better designed and less limitting - had no toxic, bad experience matches for 6 h of gameplay   cons: -imo too small amount of characters, would like to see double the number -console network system (which works fine but I understand ppl complaining) -buying starstorm dlc feels kinda like a must (but I admit its still possible to enjoy the game w/o it)  -f2p model with skins makes mobas better (though has problems like toxic players...) -xp progression system is bad, but you level up fast and its not that huge pain in the ♥♥♥ - rather small but stable and ok community

Thing is, I had for the first few hours, but over time, as I came back months after months later, the game was no longer the same. While it is an addicting game in of itself, Awesomenauts doesn't have much going for it other than the music.  Quite honestly, the music is the best part about this game. Everything else is just not up to par. Matchmaking is probably the worst offender. While they do have a league set-up, the game tends to not even match you up within the same league. If that's not enough, even if you turn the 'find players worldwide' option off, you'll still be matched with players from Australia. Coupling the bad matchmaking with the awful, unbalanced Awesomenauts, you'll find yourself irritated as you play longer and longer.  The way that they balance their Awesomenauts is through a group of players known as the 'Betanauts' who play and give suggestions on what to change. While this may not seem too bad when you first think about it, you need to know that they alone decide the metagame. Characters that are unbalanced are likely to stay that way as time goes on and other characters that don't need nerfs will get them to the point they're unusable. Furthermore, the way the game is set up, it benefits whatever team does more burst damage, to the point where you can have a team that just can't challenge the other team at all because of the matchups.  Of course, that wouldn't be a problem if you could see who the other team picked and what map you were playing on. Which you can't, of course, nor can you even communicate with your team through a chat while picking characters. Furthermore, out of the 4 maps, only 1 is even remotely good as the others are unbalanced and make the match drag on for far too long.   In my recommendation, you should honestly pass on this game. While it is addicting, it's not very fun and you're more than likely to get irritated while playing.

So, I'm going to write a real review: Awesomenauts is a fantastic game, even for those who do not like Mobas. It takes out all the clicking in one place, and replaces it with actual skill based mechanics (It's like 2D smite in that way) The characters are extremely colorful which is amazing. They all have a personality (occasionally one sided, but all unique) There are some gripes that I have though. Some of the DLC characters are slightly overpowered (i.e. one having the highest DPS in the game, excluding map hazards, available about every ten seconds) and the matchmaking system sucks. Leauge 9 players (the lowest leauge) often get paired up with players who are around leauge 2 or leauge 1. It's very rare to find a truly balanced match.   TL;DR a wonderful game with some minor issues. 8.75/10

I'm going to start off this review by saying that I do really enjoy this game from an on-paper level, and that if you want to have fun with your friends for a bit? Go ahead, this will appeal to that type of gamer. However when it comes to balance, this game, especially for one that is in the MOBA genre (dota, LoL, smite, etc) This game has to be hands down one of the most unbalanced I've ever seen.   Clear counters are not at all in place, snowballing is a massive problem, and even when the game is fairly even, some characters are incapable of proper use or play against certain other ones, and the game often comes down to character vs character if you're going to win the entire game or not. There is also a lack of communication options so expect to try and type a lot to play with strangers.   I could go on about network and reconnecting issues but they are fairly tame honestly, at least for my experience. The real issue for me was the lack of reporting options, because people will often willingly feed (get themselves killed by the enemy team on purpose) also a lot of players if they're winning extremely hard, will refuse to end the game just to drag it on and get kills. This also brings into play the lack of surrendering as an option for matchmade games, and with a game so extremely broken because of snowballing and balancing issues, you'd think surrendering would be an option.   Do you want to play this game extremely casually with friends? be my guest  Do you want a solid moba with proper balancing across all characters including dlc characters? (dont get me started) This will not be the game for you if that's what you want.

Sigh where to begin with this game? Awesomenauts is a 2d online moba, which has a roster with over 18 different heroes which are called awesomenauts. The game play just like any otheer moba if not a little easier. Its upgrade system is pretty straight forward, on each of your 4 rows in the shop (utility, autoattack, character specific ablity 1, character specific ablity 2) you get to choose out 6 upgrades per row, however you can only pick 3 items per row so choose carefully! The game looks pretty great with it art like graphics, the sfx and music is great aswell. Every character has its own theme, which can be listened to ingame when a player gets 3 kills without dying,6 kills and the last time at 9 kills. The killing spree's are all pretty good aswell. You can either play this game offline vs bots and even splitscreen. There is also ofcourse online multiplayer. However, in online matches you will defintily notice how unbalanced and unfair this game can be. And not to forget the bad match making and a lot of lag, will turn off a lot of possible playeres. The community used to be good, however it has become quite toxic and some morons will make you want to ragequit and throw your pc out of the window. These problems may not sound like much compared to the pros, but unbalanced characters and bad mathcmaking make moba a lot worse and less enjoyable then you would expect. Do i reccomend this game? yes, if you can grab it during a sale and try to make certain you have friends to play it with. Fun for the first 30 hours but because the lack of ton of online modes makes it boring afterwards. 7/10

A 2D cartoon-styled platformer/MOBA. Incudes a whole cast of characters with their own sets of upgrades and 5 different maps each with different layouts and special features, one features a blazing inferno, while another contains an antigravity device. This game also includes a great multiplayer community(apart from everyone that says Leon and Froggy G are OP)  When you join a match, there will be a red team and a blue team, each with a maximum of 3 players on each. If a player leaves a match, an AI bot will fill in the empty slot, and if a player joins, a bot will be filled in by the joining players.  There is also a DLC called Aweomenauts:Starstorm, featuring 4 new characters, with 1 more getting added in the future, and a new map. The DLC also allows you to host highly customisable custom matches.  My opinion: Worth the 10 dollars.

I miss this game, I do.    I understand my testimony is not wanted here, so I'll try to make this brief.  The game is a lot of fun. The characters are unique and interesting to play as, the gameplay sessions are intense, and the upgrade system allows each character some versatility.  The AI- mostly encountered in the Bot matches, of course, and also as substitutes for when a human player leaves a game- is very impressive. Now, this might just be because I'm so god-awful at the game, but I for one found the AI to be very challenging, and that it's easy to fall victim to them in an AI match if you let your guard down. If you want to play the game, but your internet is down, this game has definitely got you covered.  The characters themselves are very interesting, unique, and, for the most part, likable. I was particularly in love with Ayla, myself. Each one is fully voice acted. The lines written for and said by these characters are very memorable, and often funny. The vocal performances for the characters are also very well-done and likable. All of them are splendidly varied in pitch and tone, and convey emotion very well; and the vast majority of them are over-the-top in some way or another to help capture the, uh...  accessible  standards of Saturday Morning voice-acting from back in the day. Interestingly, these two traits seem to go hand in hand in each character- something I for one had long thought couldn't be the case before I played the game.  The music is great, as well- it carries that campy Saturday Morning feel, yet each track, and the soundtrack as a whole, manages to be genuinely interesting, and carry its own unique feeling- and catchy tune. And of course, in tune with the theme of the game, quite a few, namely the lyricals, have a humorous element. I used to listen to the soundtrack for hours on end without getting tired of it, myself. I found it great music for those hard work days, in particular, as well as for exercise. I'd recommend anyone reading this purchase the soundtrack, also located here on Steam, and place it in their MP3 players, as well. Of course, it's worth checking out the music on Youtube if you want to taste what you're in for; Ronimo uploads a few of its own tracks.  The Dev Team and the fan community is great, as well. Open-minded, yet rightfully scrutinous. They're very supportive of the game itself as well as of each other and any new members. They defend their own, too- I said something unacceptable of one of their well-established fans, they came to the user's defense and instituted the ban I deserve.  So, in closing:  +Fun gameplay. +Well-programmed AI. +Interesting characters. +Predominately good writing/voice acting +Fantastic soundtrack. +Great community that looks out for each other.  I'd recommend at least giving the game a try. Make the purchase, play the tutorial and a bot match or two; and let your verdict be made. I, for one, regretted maybe only a relative few sparse minutes out of the 161 hours I've played, and all of those that I remember were on account of the odd rude player or a bot name that triggered my pseudo-PTSD. This probably won't be a problem for most.  In closing, recommended.

Awesomenauts is a very interesting animal: a 2D Platforming MOBA. It incorporates all the charm of a cartoonish 2d platformer with the core elements of a PvP MOBA. Combine the two and you get a peculiar mix that appeals strongly to fans of both gametypes.  The only real downside of this game is that it doesn't make it immediately apparent that it is purely PvP. If anything, the tutorial mission seems to be leading to a singleplayer campaign, but at its conclusion you discover that this is very much not the case. The game is ONLY multiplayer, save for an offline practice mode with bots.  From a personal perspective, I found this incredibly disappointing. I was rather enthusiastic following the tutorial mission, but once it ended and I discovered the multiplayer only aspect my reaction was a puzzled, disbelieving 'wut?' I will admit that I am not the biggest PvP fan, but my disappointment goes beyond that. This game's style and mechanics virtually beg for a singleplayer campaign, and it is tragic that it is absent.  With that in mind, I can still recommend this game to MOBA fans with a fondness for 2D platformers. It definitely sets itself apart from the slew of samey crap MOBAs out there without straying too far from what makes the format popular, all while adding some unique appeal of its own. If you like team PvP, this game is pretty fun. If you want a more solo experience, you'll need to look elsewhere.

I really like Awesomenauts, I usually lack patience and strategy in most MOBA games, but Awesomenauts is the exception, I do feel it's somewhat simplified in comparison, yes, but that's not necessarly a bad thing. A game with simple mechanics can have large amounts of room for creativity, because then it's easier to learn, giving more people a chance to get creative. Although I don't agree with some of the things, like having a DLC for a bunch of new characters, and a separate DLC for a new announcer in the game, the bots aren't the most amazing, and limited as well. But the game can easily be enjoyed otherwise, the new characters are generally limited in strengths so they're not pay to win, hell, most of the people who get the DLC characters don't play all of them often. The game's still an enjoyable experience, picking from a vast group of characters with unique personalities, themes, and upgrading systems, rather than leveling up the same ways as everyone else who picks that character, you can pick your own personal upgrades for specific character abilities, as well as universal character upgrades that can mean the distance between being caught in a tight spot, or dying because you didn't have the gear to get out of said tight spot. If you don't mind a little bit of corny humor and movie references, I think this game is a good buy. Also, Ashly friggin' Burch!

Awesomenauts? Hella fun with friends.  Competitively? Terrible due to the simply unsophisticated networking. It's the host's game really due to how it's set up. The five other plebians have to make do with snipe shots hitting three different targets, the airstrikes dealing death halfway before the tell's finished, other players teleporting and attacking without key animations, and their own moves doing diddly-squat.  Oh, and the game supports splitscreen, so you might as well Alt+F4 if you see the host consists of the entire other team. You've already lost at that point.  Play locally if you want a proper experience. The online leagues are something to be ignored.  EDIT: After looking further into things, I have to state that online play in the higher leagues is NOT recommended in any way, shape, or form. Cheating is very apparent, like Skølldir running at the speed of sound, Raelynn sniping through walls, turrets, and entire bases, and characters being moved against their will without applicable moves affecting them (not due to lag, though that's cropped up too). Believe me, I've actually taken the time to study each of the suspected characters' movesets and upgrades. I'm a very sad individual.  It's pretty obvious the coding behind the game is not up to the job of weeding out modded clients, which is very disappointing, much like its failing latency compensation. The game can be so ridiculously good, but it's constantly being let down by the ineptitude of its delivery.  Definately recommend to everyone!

What to say about Awesomenauts... well. It's One of the few Great MOBAs Currently, One of the few i actually enjoy playing, It's a bit more Casual than Most MOBAs But still remains incredibly fun for the sorta 'hardcore' gamers. OVERALL:  I Highly Reccommend This Game, I feel it it is Definetally worth a try, If You Like MOBAs or platform Mechanics, then i Highly reccommend you give this game a try.

I've put some time into this game.  The art style and overall character of the game is refreshing compared to your typical modern warfare shoot'em ups and your run of the mill fantasy settings.  Compared to other MOBAs, what is particularly appealing about this game is the 2D side-scrolling gameplay. Navigating space manually with WASD/Arrow keys or a control stick gives that deliberate sense of split second control. The managing of gravity and platforming will bring out all the old childhood skills of a classic gamer. In this way the game has a more fast-paced intense experience compared to your typical point-and-click MOBA. Each character has a standard attack that does not require cool down, always giving you some say in each second of battle. If Smash Bros. could be successfully made into a MOBA then maybe I'd abandon 'Nauts for it. Until then, this is my favorite MOBA.

Awesomenauts is a great 2D MOBA platformer. The game is run with P2P multiplayer, which means that occasionally there are lag issues, depending on the host of the game; however, if the lag issues are bad, the game often switches to a better host.   Many players complain about a few 'overpowered' characters. The truth, in my opinion, is that every character is overpowered if used well, which results for an interesting balance in the game. However, Ronimo often updates and rebalances the characters as needed, and adds new characters every now and then.  It's an amazing and addictive game. If you've never played a MOBA before, this is a great game to start with. I highly recommend this game for anyone just looking to have fun, but there are competitive leagues if you're interested in that as well.

However, the game is plagued by awful systems, matchmaking and in some cases balance that are at the very core of the game. Ronimo lacks servers, which is a huge issue because lag is terrible in the peer to peer matchmaking and really ruins the fun in most matches now. Often the laggier of the teams wins, which is downright problematic in a game like this.   TLDR: Excellent gameplay ruined by poor matchmaking systems and lack of servers.

I used to play DotA. The original one. Yes, the one in Warcraft III. No, not Allstars. I'm talking Reign of Chaos here. Eul's original stuff. Back when people weren't so serious about it. You just picked a hero and had fun on a map, killing creeps, pushing towers, buying items (WITHOUT recipes). Things changed all the time. There was no 'meta'. Just fun. I dunno what happened. Maybe it finally changed for the worse. Or maybe I changed.  Things got serious. Here in 2014, DotA has exploded, and spawned so many imitations, spinoffs, knockoffs, genuine attempts at improving the formula, genuine attempts to not improve the formula whatsoever, and even it's own proper sequel. And yet, very, VERY few of them catch that original magic. When it was fun, and not an 'esport'. When it was about the objective, not the kills, and about the nice feel of it all, not the rage aimed at your peers. Here's a game of fun. But don't let the whimsy exterior fool you - it can get serious. But only serious enough. It's still fun. You pick a hero, kill some creeps, and push some towers. And it's constantly changing, evolving. I'd say it's vastly improved today compared to when I started playing, and probably even more so to when it was released! I too may have changed - I like shooters now. I didn't in the Warcraft III days. Valve showed me the way, and yet Valve's own DotA 2 doesn't hook me like the first DotA and its ilk did back in the day, or as Awesomenauts (and SMNC before it) has done now. I guess I need that shooter element now - that element of accuracy and dynamic control to contrast the numbers and upgrades. But there's more than that. Maybe I'm just and old nostalgic fool. And perhaps it is only fitting that Awesomenauts borrows its style from the saturday morning cartoons of my childhood. But you know what? Those cartoons were fun. And so is Awesomenauts.

Awesomenauts is a comic based historical documentary of the history of the russian and american space race.  Using cartoonised characters to cover the persons that were once sent into a wormhole that spawn on the west coast of alaska (from both america and russia). The game covers the intergalatic warfare that was endured for roughly 30 years when both parties found themselves in a new alien solar system.  Of course the USA government attempted to cover the return of the american 'awesomenauts' when they came back victorious after 30 years of warfare with the russians which only ended up being a whole week of our time (due to space time and ♥♥♥♥, I'm not a scientist, google this ♥♥♥♥).  The storyline is totally biased though, with undertones such as Yuri the talking russian space monkey (who speaks american, makes no damn sense). 9/10. Not a bad game.

First paid game I've ever uninstalled. Fun while it lasted, but looking back I would be in a happier place if I had burned my $9.99 instead.  The wins are fun, the losses are beyond awful. Unfortunately, wins quickly become fewer and farther between because of a TERRIBLY balanced league system. This is pretty well discussed in various forums, so do some research and you'll see that this game is not a fun long term experience. They bump up your league for no reason, and you spend the rest of your tenure being the worst player in every single match until you realize that you haven't had fun in weeks.  Characters are well balanced overall, but the strengths and weaknesses create laughable individual game matchups. Certain characters absolutely cripple others. And the game doesn't show you who has chosen whom, so you don't know until you've sat through each endless lobby that your lineup stands no chance. No strategic counter picking. Just 'oh great, a team of X, Y, and Z. There goes the next 30 minutes of my life.'  The community...awful. Angry, angry kids and racists.

The most accesible MOBA (like League of Legens or Dota 2) on the market, only 2D. The missing 3rd dimension does not spoil the gameplay or fun of this game at all. It may miss the depth of customisation of LoL or Dota but makes it up with well balanced characters that all play different. The tiered matchmaking system ensures you'll get some challenging matches. The content for price ratio in this game is fabioulos. You pay once and get the full package except some different skins that have no influence on the gameplay at all.  The music by Sönic Picnic is an other great part of the game each character has its own music set. Just check it out via google.  The game is alive and kicking, getting constant updates and balancing patches. A MUST BUY for the casual MOBA player or anyone that wants to dip the toes into the big MOBA pond.

I give it 6/10  It's a fun game and all! However it has low replayablity. Yes there's a good characters selection, but that isn't enough to make a game good. All you do is pick a character, kill towers, kill players and minions then just win. I have bought the starstorm pack and I have to say it is not worth it. The stuff like team matches, spectator mode, and replay mode should not be bought. They are part of the game, and should be added into the game free. To pay around 9 bucks just to unlock a game mode as well as other features just isn't worth it. You don't really see other many games blocking off gamemodes, and making you waste your money to buy a unfun game mode.  Yes it's a good game, but it's only fun with friends. I just wish that things weren't pre built, like forcing you to select what skills you get as you start the game. Once you chose your build there's no turning back, and you're forced to stick with it. Also the leveling system is a bit dumb, get to level 127 just to unlock one skill that you want. It's very lame, and not worth my time. Also prestige is worthless, it just shows a different icon, and no matter how good you are you will still be placed with worse players that are new to the game.   For now I don't really recommend this game.
