When the XP system first came out, I hated it and for good reason. The XP system at first was a hot mess, it was unbalanced and hated everyone, but now it's been patched it's actually not too bad now honestly.  I still prefer the old system for playing offline with friends, but from a competetive standpoint, this is one of the best XP systems in all MOBAs, it actually allows comebacks to happen albeit infrequently.  Most people have gotten over the XP system by this point, it's a change and it wasn't good at first, but if you're still one of those people who hate it, give it a chance, it's better excecuted than you think. (It still needs bugfixing)  Awesomenauts itself is a great game, it's a fast and exciting game with very few problems. The matchmaking isn't there yet and the balancing (while better than most other mobas) isn't perfect either, but it's still a blast to play with friends and acceptable to play online, even though the netcode is a bit shoddy.

Time to review my favourite (and most played) game in my library.  Awesomenauts is a 2D, side-scrolling MOBA centered on 3 vs 3 fast paced matches with a more casual feel than other games in the genre. It is made by Ronimo Games, a small team based in the Netherlands.  The graphics are great, as is the smooth gameplay (any latency aside that is). The soundtrack is very good too. The only thing I have against the game is it's use of peer to peer rather than servers. But for the most part, as long as you stay in your own region or close to, that isn't much of a problem.  The game also has a great sense of humour, with many of the characters, or their respective scripts, making reference to other games and parts of pop culture.  Your first few matches may be a trial by fire as you start in the lower leagues where toxity reigns and ignorance is bliss. But after some perserverance you'll see the community for what it actually is; Friendly, helpfull and funny. You do need to get to at least league 5 (of 9. League 1 being the top, as you may expect) to see this though. This is much easier with friends than it is going solo, but the latter is still capable of leveling up, league-wise. It's just pot luck as to who you'll be matched with if you decide to do things that way.  In summary, Awesomenauts is one of the best value for money games on Steam IMO. It is frequently on sale for peanuts as well, so even more value. It is constanly updated with rebalancing and extra content (it started with 5 playable characters and now has 21, soon to be 22 (5 of which are DLC)) and even has a complete rework in the pipe-line as far as matchmaking goes, so less being matched with people outside your region and league.   I think you should buy it immediately.

This results in all players feeling that their attack was spot on and that the lag is the other player's loss. Then the lag attacks them for a change and it becomes 'the crying game' where lag is not as nice as you thought it was.  Much less stressful than Dota2 but due to lacking servers, expect to be frustrated when you are mixed with awful players even though you are rank 1. Expect to lose rank fast unless you have friends you do well with.  Update: between certain hours the game is unplayable. Having issues with people on wireless where their lag jumps from 185 to 600+ and somehow hosts disconnect from their own game which they are hosting. Then there are people close to the host that have an advantage over people far from the host because of the way their actions and updates are faster than those that are further away. Great potential for the game but lack of servers to iron out the spikes in lag result in frustrating gameplay.

UPDATE: I am happy to say they finally fixed the level lead imbalance! Now it is quite possible to make a come back from any point in the game, which restores a significant part of the competative outlook in Awesomenauts. So whats the remaining problem? Well following the release of the Overdrive expansion, the three new characters are dominating every round, even against players who are far ahead of them on the leader boards. Naturally this happens with new releases and it will be balanced shortly, as it was with the Starstorm expansion. So why is this being mentioned?  MATCH-MAKING...THIS is the number one problem with Awesomenauts as it has been since the release of the game. Time and time again you get paired with League 3-6 players against League 1-2 masters. WHY IS THIS STILL HAPPENING?! It is NOT complicated to put in blocks and balances for these type of player joins and match-making. I, and many other players I regularly play with, have recently dropped from League 2 or higher down to 3-5! Why? Because we are suddenly being paired with extremely low ranked players agains higher ranked players who join up, or simple due to bad match making. There is NO excuse for this kind of bad player matching algorithme in the year 2016!  RONIMO! FIX YOUR GAME'S match making before rolling out any other updates or expansions! Base team compositions on player's K/D ratios and League rank, and stop allowing high league players to gang-bang moderate to low players in order to maintain their ranking! It is NOT hard to do! If this is fixed the game will once again be great! Until then it is lacking, frustrating, and poorly orchestrated.  _______________________________________________________________________________ Previous Review: I 'DID' love awesomenauts. It was the best part of my day everyday after work. Then they rolled out the XP system and now it isn't any fun, nor is it fair at all. Here's why:  All it takes is a 2+ level lead and 90% of the time that team will win. Think about this logically. If a team gets an early lead what sense does it make to not only reward them with more solar than the other team but NOW to ALSO boost their damage and health, significantly, this making them even stronger than before?...It's insanity! Almost every game is determined in the first 1-2 minutes due to who gets the first kill and consequently a level lead.   You can be the best player in the game but if your teammates make ONE wrong move the other team will now have such a strong solar and level lead that they are neigh unbeatable. I've had SO many games since this update where I was the top scoring player in the game (We're talking 10+ kills to 0 deaths) and I lost, sometime 6-10 games in a ROW simply because my teammates made little mistakes in the beginning.  End comment: It should NEVER be as difficult as it is for a team to make a come back. This patch rewards an early lead so heavily that I can only compare it to a wrestling match between a strong guy and a slightly less strong guy, in which the game makers see the strong guy and delusionally think it would be a good idea to give him steriods in order to make him even more difficult to beat. They call that balance?...No, the scales are now tipped so horribly that the game isn't ANY FUN to play anymore!  FIX IT or I'm not ever buying DLC or playing another match again. 99% of the players I've talked to in game HATE the XP system, even when they're winning! STOP IGNORING US!

A fun game? I was a little put off when they released a paid expansion, however, after I had already bought the game.   This was not even just extra heroes--what annoyed me was they included updates and new things for the game system in the expansion! They did add other heroes after, but that was annoying for me.  Another thing: cosmetics are not free. You paid for the game but want extra cosmetics? Haha, no.   I'm sorry, but other games like DotA 2 and Smite at least allow you to play the game for free, get cosmetics for free, and get heroes for free.  edit: another expansion added, again costs money. I really like the idea of Awesomenauts, but this is not how you compete with free games which are handing out free items. In Awesomenauts, you pay for the game, the expansions, extra announcers, and skins! You get nothing for free. You even have to keep playing to unlock heroes (so even with the original game you bought you don't get everything). Either they should have made it free and done this (which I would consider fine, where everything else besides core game costs money) or they should have made every extra thing onto the plain game I bought free (or at least unlockable through playing the game).   I guess it seems logical. You want player to play the game more, right? So make things unlockable through playing. Heck, even if it took 1000 games to unlock an expansion I'd probably be suckered into doing it ...

Would be more fun if it were better balanced. Unfortunately new characters are nearly always OP, not simply because they change the meta but for literal overpoweredness. Lately I have been playing one of the OP characters but even I can't do much against someone playing Gnaw who knows what they're doing, Gnaw inevitably becomes the highest level 'naut in every game I play because not only is he an effective melee fighter, but he has huge poison attacks, a huge AOE poison attack that sticks around, and he drops turrets which can be upgraded to be really annoying, and they don't even reward you when you die 3 times to clear them out of a corner under or above a lane. The turrets also allow Gnaw to dominate the entire jungle, constantly killing the neutral creeps as soon as they spawn or distracting the jungle bosses (the jungle bosses can't attack around corners, so they just stand there uselessly trying to kill the turrets that are next to them), giving Gnaw constant money and health. In short, his build isn't even very difficult to put together, his attacks require very little skill, and if you know even a little about jungling then you will wreck every game if you play Gnaw. My favorite character, Lonestar, was nerfed a while back and I find him utterly useless to play now. It is nearly impossible for me to get good kills with him unless someone else is setting up ganks for me. On his own, he is terrible now. I appreciate tremendously that the devs are constantly trying to add new things, but expect to pay for each new character or expansion. It is certainly not expensive, I've dropped maybe 30 or 40 dollars on the game for many hours of gameplay and I don't buy a lot of skins. The matchmaking system is also quite frustrating, because I get a lot of kills as Raelynn, my OP 'naut of choice, I get put with teams of complete newbies very frequently. Doesn't matter if I get more kills than everyone else in the game put together, having a team of people who don't even fight the enemy or don't observe obvious opportunities to gank will mean I lose nearly every game despite my tremendous lead in levels and damage output. Also if you go into Quick games, expect it to constantly put you in the same group of people over and over, and even the same games over and over after you've quit them. I've quit a lot of games, I'll admit, because I can't stand the people flaming, trolling, or playing horrendously, and when I click into matchmaking it puts me back in the same game. It seems to me like matchmaking needs just a few small tweaks and I would be a lot less unhappy. When matchmaking screws me I end up quitting, without any other choice, really. I have to wait for some of those people in my region to stop playing or diffuse into other groups of players in matchmaking so that I don't constantly end up with the same 3 jackasses. If you are just getting into the game and you know even a little about jungling and stuttering from other MOBA titles then you will probably appreciate the simplified, arcade-style gameplay in Awesomenauts. Games are fast, you don't spend a long time doing nothing as in other MOBAs, there are even maps that force you into direct combat before the creeps even spawn. Character powers are all quite varied, and can be customized so that they do completely different things, and there are a few characters that have different modes where they do a completely different array of actions, allowing you to walk into battle a harrasser-pusher and walk out if it having murdered everyone as a tank with a DPS aura. The varied nature of the characters means that every game is different, different combinations of characters obviously work well together compared to others but a lot of the time you won't know what your allies are going to be until you're already in the game, so you'll often end up trying to get creative to win a game against some people with a good combination of, for example, an assassin, a tank and a puller-AOE who set up ganks you can't avoid unless you never walk in front of your tower. The loadouts you pick before a game can also vary widely, and you can even put completely opposed upgrades in there so that during the game you can buy the items that make sense for a situation rather than adhering to a strict build, and you'll still do fine against people with an OP build sometimes, because you chose to be flexible. Lastly, this game appeals to people familiar with youth TV of the 80s and 90s, and videogames of the past 20 years. You will enjoy this game a lot more if you understand all the oneliners (there are probably hundreds) and recognize all the visual references. Some gaming personalities voice some of the characters so if you are into the gaming segment of Youtube you may enjoy playing as your favorite Youtuber. Personally I like Jesse Cox and Totalbiscuit as well as Dodger but I don't really like playing their characters, I end up playing that Yogscast guy, Lewis I guess, but his character's humor is up my alley anyway. If you queue up with a team you may have a better experience. But expect a much more classic arcade form of MOBA, and in my opinion more fun and still with a high skill ceiling (though arguably not nearly as high as DOTA).  Unfortunately every patch seems to make something really OP and something that was average really ♥♥♥♥♥♥. This trend has been continuous since day 1 and I've quit this game, I'm tired of skill having nothing to do with wins and losses.

Any easy to learn MOBA style game with fun comic-like graphics and humour. The basics are the same: there is a map (actually, many maps in this case) with multiple lanes connecting two bases to each other, and from your base automatic minions march forward to the other base, trying to destroy it. There are towers on each lane, defending the bases, and you choose a champion to play with to assist your miniature army and in the end, destroy the enemy base. Characters are unique and fun to play, and there are a lot interesting mechanisms thanks to the 2D platformer enviroment. The learning curve is very user friendly, nothing like LoL or DotA2 where you need to spend countless hours, days, weeks, even months to learn and experience all the matchups, get used to the itemization system and everything. You still level up, you still buy 'items' (it's merged with skill leveling at level ups), but it takes 5-10 minutes, a half hour top to get used to the system and the characters, and it's not getting boring at all later on. A must have for everyone who likes the genre but can't / don't want to afford the time it takes to really get into it. It's on sale for ridicolously low price pretty often on various sites, so keep your eyes open!

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

Is it possible to be worse than a free-to-play game? Yes, it is. This game proves it.  While the game does have some positives, such as simpler matches, it doesn't do it any justice against the overwhelming negatives. The 'shop' system for in game battles for one. The game 'locks' some in game upgrades for all characters until your 'account level' is increased. Based on my first time experiancing the game, you can't upgrade your account level until you've completed the games tutorial missions, which range from killing an enemy player (A.I. or Player) to spending 3,000 'solars' in the games shop.  As for upgrades, you can apparently only choose three upgrades for each individual skill, something the game neglected to inform you on.  As well, where in most games you can see each skill, a demonstration of the skills, and what the upgrades are for those skills, you can't in this game. You don't even get a game countdown to prep for the battle, so while you're facing veteran players on your first day of playing (excluding the free weekend at the time of writing this, there are only about 800-1,400 players that regulary play, so yes, odds are you'll be facing veteran players constantly), you'll be at a loss and far behind others on your team while you're trying to understand the shop and figure out what to buy.  The characters themselves are very cartoony in apparence, and sound like they belong in a 1990's saturday morning cartoon, with very little animation to them. I think one character literally doesn't have an animation for anything. She just kind spins her entire character around.   In short, this game might be more targeted towards children, and definately not worth the money for your MOBA needs. You really are better off sticking to something like League of Legends, DOTA, or Smite.

A PvP side scrolling shooter!? Oh hell yes, sign me up. How could you possibly screw this up? By making it a MOBA and trying to balance it, that's how. Oh, and of course failing in the most basic way there is to fail in a platformer: bad controls.  MOBAs are another gift from those wacky warcraft 3 modders. And like all profitable genres, it's being done to death. I hear they're doing a care bear moba. Anyway, Awesomenauts' twist on the standard formula is to turn it into a 2d side scrolling shooter and to pretend to have style by making everything AWESOME! with caps and exclamation points and everything. The art style is actually sort of good, but making everything AWESOME! gets old in a hurry.  As far as gameplay goes, the game is so close, and yet not there. The best way to describe the problem with the game is that it doesn't want to be a platformer, it wants to be another lame top down LoL clone. There's no real twitch factor in the game and ranges are too short for anything other than spamming the attack key and praying for the best to work. Characters feel slow, sluggish, and tragically underpowered.  Here's the thing, I want to love this game, but it won't let me. In addition to the bad controls, the MOBA trappings simply get in the way. Lane control, turrets, creeps, minions...they're all here and no fun at all to play against. I say get out of the way and let us duke it out, man to octopus thing.

I own Awesomenauts on four different platforms (PC, PS4, PS3, Xbox360) and have put a couple hundred hours into it - I usually don't stick with one game for such a long period of time. Awesomenauts has a perfect mix of competition and fun. Not to mention it has couch co-op. Lots of characters to choose from, each with their own unique builds. Tons of replayability and easy to learn. If you love the MOBA genre and find games like DOTA or LOL requiring too much of your time to learn, give Awesomenauts a try.  The only down side is the community. Like any competitive game, people can get a little testy when it comes to losing. If your team loses a game, it's specifically your fault. If you're murdering people left and right, your character is OP. If you have zero deaths at the end of a match, you're hacking. The Internet is eternally ignorant and the Awesomenauts community is no exception.

It's a side scrolling MoBA!  That's litterally all there is to it. You have your base that you have to defend with numerous heros to chose from. You have to break through enemy turrets and their forces to destroy their base before they destroy yours while gathering currency from killing waves of creeps to purchase upgrades for you hero. Upgrading is simply compared to other games of this genre, you simply upgrade the skill you want to enhance which makes just jumping into the game easier for beginners.  Pros: - Cartoony art style - Great voice acting for the characters (A few famous internet celebs lend their voices) - Characters differ nicely from one another - Easy to pick up and get into for people that have never played MoBAs before - Skills are bound to the mouse so it makes WASD movement easier  Cons: - A bit simple and nothing too different from other MoBAs other than it's 2D - Some characters seem a bit stronger than others because of their kits - The maps might be different from one to the next, but they're not THAT different

Once I had experimented with each character for a bit to see which one I should be, I picked one and almost felt a connection with that character. Kinda like how you become an 'name of character here' main in Smash bros.   Getting kills and doing well really is satisfying, especially if you get a kill streak going. Your character's theme plays in the background and it makes you feel even more patriotic about your character.   ALTHOUGH, on the other hand there is a massive problem with lag and connection. Players with very poor internet benefit from this, as they can go around killing everyone and the people with good internet can't do anything because they just die without an enemy in sight. This makes high level play with strangers very hard, as people either have crappy internet, or forcibly create those conditions so that they can win more games.  OVERALL, when you do get a match with nice people, all of whom have good internet, then the game is a dream to play. There is a lot of variety and play styles between the characters, and individual characters can be played very differently depending on the loadouts you give them. I reckon this is a great game to play, but give every character a shot. You may be very surprised who you fall in love with.  P.S. Screw you Nibbs

I am recommending this game. I don't want to, but I am. The reason I am recommending this game is every time I play it, I get a sense of quality. I never get to experience this quality, but I'm sure it's there somewhere.  The game is, in a word, 'fun'. All the characters are well made and have their own unique play styles. The gameplay itself is action packed and the fact that a remix of a characters theme plays upon a killstreak is one of my favorite parts. In fact, the only reason I don't like this game is that everything goes wrong for me. Everything. From the internet crashing( Which makes the game think you rage-quit and drops you back down to leagues) to the other team being incredibly cheap to the game not sending me a replacement player and dooming me to lose because of a inept bot, the odds are always stacked against me. Well they did it. They killed awesomenauts. It's sad to see this once impressive game make a complete 180. What makes it even more sad is that it was one decision. That decision was level up in match system(a lot like many of the popular mobas where for the match your charachter levels up in the match but after the match ends those levels are gone).  So what makes the level up decision so bad? Well it ruins any hope of recovery from falling behind. Awesomenauts used to be a game where a team could comeback from what seemed to be a defeat to just barely win. Now it's just get ahead then watch as the enemy team can't do anything. This also doesn't help another bad decision made a while back in which they decided to change from a set of powerups they could buy throughout the course of the game that would be available to pick from for anyone playing that charachter to locking some powerups level requirements which doesn't help that you will get in game with players at random levels.  So should you buy awesomenauts? The answer from me sadly is no, not in its current state. I hope they realize that these decisions were seriously detremental to the game, and work to fix these problems.

Awesomenauts is a MOBA. Well, sort of. If you took a platformer/shooter and mashed it into DotA or League of Legends, and sprinkle a bit of 80s Saturday morning cartoons on top, and you'll have Awesomenauts. It certainly is unique.   Gameplay  Awesomenauts plays like a 2d shooter, with abilities and perks that you can level up like in MOBA titles. Teams spawn on either side of a two-level map, with a goal to destroy the enemy base. There ist a leveling system in matches, but you buy and upgrade your abilities with Solar, the equivalen to match gold. This means it's a little harder to get 'fed,' as levels are more for lategame scaling than anything else. That's not to say it isn't possible for a team to get 'fed,' however comebacks are still possible. Even the tankiest of tanks can still be taken down fairly quickly. The turrets (towers) are impassable until you destroy them, which are difficult to take down alone as they do massive damage very quickly. Combat itself is fast-paced, and rewards speed and accuracy. Many heroes have skillshots which are incredibly satisfying to combo properly.  Features  Awesomenauts has a cartoonish art style that reminds me of 80s sci fi shows. It can be off-putting to some, but I find it unique and enjoyable. There are 18 heroes currently available with the base game, and another four and three with the two DLC expansions. Each hero has their own unique personality and backstory, and they are so incredibly different you'll never have problems telling them apart. You unlock new heroes and different skill perks by progressing through a skill path, which you can progress through fairly quickly. Plus, each hero has their own theme! I wish more games did that.  Future  Awesomenauts still gets regular updates, with new heroes and maps still being added. The devs even organize tournaments from time to time, with decent prize pools. The community is small compared to games like League of Legends or DotA, but it is still very active, and you'll have no problem finding matches.  TL;DR Awesomenauts is a fresh take on the MOBA genre, with a unique aesthetic and an arcadey but fun combat system. Although the player pool is small, it is still active, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a unique spin on this type of game!

My brothers and I got this game a few weeks ago, and it's been fun to check out. We really liked the art style and zany flavor of the game. Awesomenauts has a lot of fun elements: A good sense of humor, bright visuals, and a good amount of action. Each hero gets their own theme music and the game itself is pretty fun. That's the good stuff. However, the matchmaking is TERRIBLE! The matchmaking seems to be unable to distinguish experienced players from newbies. Naturally, it's frustrating to be decimated repeatedly when you're trying to learn a game. Also, if you think this is a fun game to play solo, think again. DO NOT play this game solo! You'll end up with bots on your team and the opposition tends to focus on real players when that happens. Despite its fun bright appearance, this game is not friendly to new players. Like many MOBAs, this game requires some study before one can expect to be competitive, and while you study you can expect to be fighting people who already know what they're doing... Yeah, real fun... Also, even though it allows controller support, this game's overall mechanics really don't work well with a controller. (As a big fan of platformers, this was very disappointing to me.) I originally bought the game because I like MOBAs but wanted to get away from the nasty LoL and HoN communities... you'll find more of the same here. Tired of seeing 'u mad bro?' and all the other overused memes? Look elsewhere then. That said, if you've played MOBAs before, have a fondness for platformers, are willing to invest more time in another game with a very steep learning curve, and will be bringing some friends along, totally check this game out. Otherwise, I would not recommend this game to people.

Awesomenauts is a lot of fun, and a very unique game. The premise is to turn DotA into a Saturday morning cartoon, and flip the action from top down to side scrolling. There is a variety of maps and each Awesomenaut gets a unique set of 'items' that count as abilities and ability upgrades, unifying the gold / xp resource system into just a single resource to manage. Graphically, it is very kid friendly and humorous, but the action is satisfying for all ages. Battles are typically fought 3v3 and it is up to each player to master their abilities and work as a team to push their wave of robots into the enemy defenses, eventually destroying them on the way to the enemy base. I love this game and plan to try spending some more time with it.  Oh and, while some heroes are locked when you begin playing, they unlock VERY quickly just by playing matches and there is no need to spend any money or any ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like that.

This game is a great combination of a fast paced moba and a platformer, your goal and object to the game is moba style but the combat is much faster slightly lest strategic but definatly more fun over all. unlike most mobas now a days that have anywhere between 30 - 100 characters which is just more than you even have time to test out. awesomenauts offers very few unique characters that all offer a fun interesting and veriety of playing styles. i would recoment this game to anyone who wants to try at a new moba style game. awesomenauts did a good job at keeping all the characters pretty even, there isnt one character who is better than the others, it is all about the play style you prefer and what character can offer that for you. i also liked how awesomenauts offers their starstorm DLC including 4 additional characters, just having this option adds a whole different style to your game. The final reason awesomenauts is good for you is because most mobas dont do a very good job at seperating experienced players from non experienced players, but awesomenauts splits the ranks up evenly to keep play fair. the community in this game is fun and caring, There isnt any online'chirping' and anything that does happen isnt tollerated. I would rate this game 8/10

Without going into detail, just know you're going to see a same few characters played very frequently which require little skill to dominate games. Whether this is your 1st MOBA or your 10th, this is game is only to be played in short bursts or if you enjoy seeing who can play the most broken characters the best, and with that huge roadblock of frustration in mind, I can not recommend this to anyone who wants to play it for more than an hour or two at a time.

This is the first multi-player tower defense game I've ever played, having picked it up in a Humble Bundle somewhere. The game characters are quite varied, I've enjoyed them all, and I'm glad to see expansion in this area. I do, however, find myself often wishing for more arenas. The ones there are great, but more are desperately needed.  Other players seem much tougher to beat now versus when I first started playing Awesomenauts back in August, probably because I took a few months off. I also see a lot more players teaming up now than when I first started playing (either via local co-op or flashing the same clan tags). This teamwork is usually the key to winning, and it is immensely difficult or impossible to beat a well-organized team. That said, this game has surprised me more than once with down-to-the-last-tower-comeback-from-behind wins against overconfident teams.  I've had many good experiences with other players, but lately it's been not as good. I think the Starstorm expansion soured some of the community both by bringing in inexperienced-and-frustrated noobs and by giving people a scapegoat with an expanded for-pay character.  And yet, I still haven't met anyone in person who has heard of Awesomenauts. It just seems like a small community of players. Maybe that's because there's no 'search mode' for joining in-progress matches.  Finally, never rage quit. Be a good sport and finish well. Don't trash your teammates. This is a game folks. I really, really, wish there was a reputation system or other mechanism for avoiding some of the immature members of the community.

A 2-D platformer MOBA. The dev did an amazing job combining the concept of a MOBA game with an old-school platforming, the main objective is to destroy the opponent's towers and eventually their drill (core). The game has tons of classes/characters to choose from,each with 2 unique active abilites that you can upgrade.  The charcacters range from healer to harrasser, but you have the freedom to use them with your own prefered playstyle by choosing the correct loadout of upgrades (24 different upgrades for each classes/characters). For example,you choose wether this certain skill will stun an enemy or do damge over time instead,or if it will blind or silence the enemy.  The platforming is a HUGE aspect of the game platforming can save your life or take it away from you, so in order to win have to be good not only in MOBA games such as dota,LoL,etc, you have to bee good in platfroming games such as super meat boy (a hard one i might add).  definetly worth 10 dollars or 2.49 dollars (cause this game is on a discount most of the times)

Bottom Line Up Front: If you have a friend (or 2) who will play the game with you it's worth the $10 USD it currently costs. If you don't fall into that category, save your money for something that will be a little more enjoyable in the long run.  Pros: -Decent mechanics. The way you build your character as the game progresses definatley matters and can play a major role in winning or losing; as can character selection. -In the same vein as the first one, characters are plenty and you can spend hours just playing through them to figure out what you like. Then there's the matter of finding your 'build' for that character. -Smooth gameplay. Disregarding actual latency issues from a player (very small occurence) the gameplay was smooth. Something that deserves mention considering there aren't dedicated servers and instead each person acts as the 'host' in a small P2P networked match. -Very replayable. Matches last for ~20 minutes. And from when you click launch you can be in a match in less than 5 minutes. After a match you can be in another in less than 3. During peak times it's about 1.5 minutes. It makes it a very nice game when you are low on time or don't want a huge time committment to have a quick enjoyable match.  Cons -Because there are no dedicated servers, the game decides who's hitbox is 'right' by going with whoever cast an ability. If someone is lagging and throw's a nuke your way even if you dodge it on your screen, if they see it as hitting you then they hit you. Some folks purposely lag their computer to get an advantage. It's a very small subset of the already small population but it's there. I hesitated adding this but since it isn't free to play you should know what you're paying for. (Funny side note: I once played a guy who in game name was 'I only lag in nauts' or something like that.) -You don't have access to all of your skills until you have leveled more in the game. It puts you at a disadvantage against the players who have been playing for a bit. It's a fairly quick leveling process. I'm almost done at almost 40 hours of gameplay. How quickly you level will depend on how often you win ... which feeds into the next and biggest con.  -And finally, the reason I can't recommend this game. The player base for this game is miniscule compared to other games and the singleplayer is extremely lackluster. As a result of the small playerbase, premade groups are in the same queue as solo players. If you don't have a friend who is in this game and you decide to dedicate some time to it, you will move up to a league where it seems all you play is premade groups who are on voip. They roll around stomping pubbers and have the nerve to talk trash while they do it. All of my games for about the last 2.5 hours of gaming has been this. The whole experience makes the game itself unenjoyable. At this point I'm trying to decide whether I should find a real MOBA or wreck my stats to drop down into a bracket where I find less of them. If you decide to look it up, you can find posts about it every year since it came out.

Spent some time in the game and went up from League 9 (start) to Leage 7 (bronze) twice before I decided to uninstall again. This could have been an awesome game, the gameplay is nice and the characters are well done. But there are three main reasons making the game barely fun at all:  1) But the matchmaking is extremely broken. I had countless situations where I was teamed with another noob and a bot vs. two or three(!) Prestige 9 players. Today, again my first match consisted of 2 prestige vs a random+me and as a fifth player joined after 1 turret of ours is already destroyed, the game puts him into the other team as well, still leaving us with the bot. Needless to say, we lost. I feel sorry for the last player that joined our team few minutes before losing, though.  2) To make things worse, there aren't nearly enough players available, even on a saturday evening. More often than not you wait the full 3:00 minute timer and still join with bots, even when Player Search is set to 'worldwide'.  3) And because there are no dedicated servers, you usually wait full three minutes to have a game with 1-2 bots and a host on another continent, leading to lags and rubberbanding for everyone else but the host.  In conclusion, I think that point 2) is a result of the combination of 1) and 3). Fixing the issue with dedicated servers would take additional money that the developers may not have, understandable to a point (although a stricter rule for max. Ping would already help). But the unfair matchmaking could be fixed easily and simply has not been done for ages, see google results for 'awesomenauts matchmaking'. Is it necessary to put another joining Prestige 9 into a group of 2 Prestige 7-9s instead of the other team with 2 'normal' ones?  If you have a very high frustration tolerance, this might still be a game for you. For me, it's definitely not.

Dota 2. League of Legends. Smite. Say what you will about MOBA's, but you can't deny their popularity. These games present challenges and commitments that can be enjoyed with friends, so they hold a lot of appeal for a lot of people. Super Monday Night Combat has demonstated that a MOBA playstyle, structure, and map can work in a third person shooter, but Awesomenauts took it one step further.  Awesomenauts is a 2D, platforming, PvP, incredibly fun game, and I would reccomend it to new players interested in playing a MOBA for the first time or old hats in the ring wanting to try a different game. It's fun, well made, with excellent mechanics and a great artstyle. Some stipulations before going in: balance. There is a levelling system and Gnaw is so totally overpowered that having one of THOSE players will ruin the entire game. The sniper, Raelynn, and the tank, Derpl, have some individual issues that are harder to abuse, but still present. One map spawns extra flying bots that make the game longer, and another has a large creep that is somewhat obnoxious. Other than that, I would heartily reccomend the game. Hope to see you ingame sometime.

Some people say that this WAS a good game, that the devs killed it with the latest update. Some people complain that the team based XP system makes for very one-sided matches. This is still a good game, a fun game. The goal of this game is not to simply 'win', if all you wanted was a bunch of victories and kill streaks then go copy someone else's 'perfect meta', copy and paste the same character every match. The real draw of this game is to figure out the niche each character can fill through hours of experimentation and class customization. It's okay to die as long as you learn from it (or at least go out in a spectacular fashion). The most fun I had with this game was when I was experimenting with 'offensive healer' and 'Hit-and-run-BS-OMG-you-kill-stealing-***' classes, and staging epic half hour land stands with a friend in local coop even though we had no chance of turning it around.  In conclusion, this is a fun game and it should be played for fun. It just takes a while to get used to. And you're always underpowered.

A year or so ago I would have recommended this game. It's fun to play when things are working well, but the more time you invest into it the more frustrating it becomes.   The game has a lot going for it. Awesomenauts is much faster paced than your traditional mobas like LoL or DotA, and the active playstyles of most nauts reflect this. Each character has their own form of jump and 2 different abilities that can be augmented with the items you buy in the shop to do different things. The games artstyle and music is charming and gives an 80's tv show feel, adding a sort of nostalgia to the game.  However, the game suffers horribly from ping(lag) advantages, if someone's over 200-250 ping expect to be hit by abilities outside of their normal hitboxes. Matchmaking falters because of the low playerbase of the game, so people who aren't as skilled get paired up with higher ranked players simply because there isn't anyone else to que with.  Ronimo said that they were going to implement a matchmaking server to hopefully reduce the lag and other problems, but that was almost a year and a half ago (current date is february 2nd 2016) and we haven't seen any development on that front. Instead we got an xp and level system out of the blue that no one really wanted.   I'd stop playing the game, but I've made quite a few friends through it and haven't been able to find a seperate game that we can all enjoy for as long as we have this game. So though I may not like it, with the time i've spent already I feel obligated to continue.

Awesomenauts is a MOBA. Well, sort of. If you took a platformer/shooter and mashed it into DotA or League of Legends, and sprinkle a bit of 80s Saturday morning cartoons on top, and you'll have Awesomenauts. It certainly is unique.   Gameplay  Awesomenauts plays like a 2d shooter, with abilities and perks that you can level up like in MOBA titles. Teams spawn on either side of a two-level map, with a goal to destroy the enemy base. There ist a leveling system in matches, but you buy and upgrade your abilities with Solar, the equivalen to match gold. This means it's a little harder to get 'fed,' as levels are more for lategame scaling than anything else. That's not to say it isn't possible for a team to get 'fed,' however comebacks are still possible. Even the tankiest of tanks can still be taken down fairly quickly. The turrets (towers) are impassable until you destroy them, which are difficult to take down alone as they do massive damage very quickly. Combat itself is fast-paced, and rewards speed and accuracy. Many heroes have skillshots which are incredibly satisfying to combo properly.  Features  Awesomenauts has a cartoonish art style that reminds me of 80s sci fi shows. It can be off-putting to some, but I find it unique and enjoyable. There are 18 heroes currently available with the base game, and another four and three with the two DLC expansions. Each hero has their own unique personality and backstory, and they are so incredibly different you'll never have problems telling them apart. You unlock new heroes and different skill perks by progressing through a skill path, which you can progress through fairly quickly. Plus, each hero has their own theme! I wish more games did that.  Future  Awesomenauts still gets regular updates, with new heroes and maps still being added. The devs even organize tournaments from time to time, with decent prize pools. The community is small compared to games like League of Legends or DotA, but it is still very active, and you'll have no problem finding matches.  TL;DR Awesomenauts is a fresh take on the MOBA genre, with a unique aesthetic and an arcadey but fun combat system. Although the player pool is small, it is still active, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a unique spin on this type of game!

Awesomenauts is a fresh take on the MOBA genre, combining 2D platforming elements with the objective and team based gameplay of MOBAs. Unlike most other MOBAs, it is easy to pick up and learn, but is hard to master and requires practice and a well coordinated team to push and take down objectives. It features all of the standard elements of MOBA games, with the main objective being to destroy the enemy team's base while protecting your own. It features a large cast of humorous characters, all being unique and with a different purpose. The voice acting and soundtrack are amazing and fit the cartoony style of graphics well. Overall, it's a great game and worth looking into. You can spend hours on end playing this game and never get bored, even for people who are not familiar with the MOBA genre.
